description: From Middle English wax, from Old English weax, from Proto-Germanic *wahsƒÖ, possibly from Proto-Indo-European *wo·∏±-so-. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Woaks (‚Äúwax‚Äù), West Frisian waaks (‚Äúwax‚Äù), Dutch was (‚Äúwax‚Äù), German Wachs (‚Äúwax‚Äù), Norwegian voks (‚Äúwax‚Äù); and with Lithuanian va≈°kas (‚Äúwax‚Äù), Proto-Slavic *vosk—ä (‚Äúwax‚Äù).

examples: What role does the wax in your earhole fulfill?

entries.meaning: Any oily, water-resistant, solid or semisolid substance; normally long-chain hydrocarbons, alcohols or esters.
Any preparation containing wax, used as a polish.
(uncountable, music, informal) The phonograph record format for music.
(US, dialect) A thick syrup made by boiling down the sap of the sugar maple and then cooling it.
(US, slang) A type of drugs with as main ingredients weed oil and butane; hash oil.

description: From Middle English waxen, from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: wax (third-person singular simple present waxes, present participle waxing, simple past and past participle waxed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To apply wax to (something, such as a shoe, a floor, a car, or an apple), usually to make it shiny.
examples: Synonyms: buff, shine, polish, furbish, burnish

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove hair at the roots from (a part of the body) by coating the skin with a film of wax that is then pulled away sharply.
(transitive, slang) To kill, especially to murder a person.
examples: Synonyms: bump off, knock off, whack; see also Thesaurus:kill

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic, usually of a musical or oral performance) To record. [from 1900]

description: From Middle English waxen, from Old English weaxan (‚Äúto wax, grow, be fruitful, increase, become powerful, flourish‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *wahsijanƒÖ (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *h‚ÇÇweg- (‚Äúto grow, increase‚Äù). Cognate with Scots wax (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), West Frisian waakse (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), Low German wassen, Dutch wassen (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), German wachsen (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), Danish and Norwegian vokse (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), Swedish v√§xa (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), Icelandic vaxa (‚Äúto grow‚Äù), Gothic êçÖêå∞êå∑êçÉêåæêå∞êåΩ (wahsjan, ‚Äúto grow‚Äù); and with Ancient Greek ·ºÄŒ≠ŒæŒµŒπŒΩ (a√©xein), Latin auxilium. It is in its turn cognate with augeo. See eke.

verbs.description: wax (third-person singular simple present waxes, present participle waxing, simple past waxed or (archaic) wex or (obsolete) wox, past participle waxed or (dialectal, archaic) waxen)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative, literary) To increasingly assume the specified characteristic.
examples: to wax poetic ‚Äï to become increasingly verbose
to wax wode ‚Äï to become angry

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of the moon) To appear larger each night as a progression from a new moon to a full moon.
(intransitive, of the tide) To move from low tide to high tide.

description: Uncertain; probably from phrases like to wax angry, wax wode, and similar (see Etymology 2, above).

entries.meaning: (dated, colloquial) An outburst of anger, a loss of temper, a fit of rage.
examples: ‚ÄòThat's him to a T,‚Äô she would murmur; or, ‚ÄòJust wait till he reads this‚Äô; or, ‚ÄòAh, won't that put him in a wax!‚Äô
